revision.text:
{{Otherships|HMS Orwell}} {|{{Infobox ship begin}} {{Infobox ship image |Ship image= |Ship caption= }} {{Infobox ship career |Hide header= |Ship country=United Kingdom |Ship flag= {{shipboxflag|United Kingdom|naval}} |Ship name=HMS ''Orwell'' |Ship namesake= |Ship ordered= |Ship awarded= |Ship builder= [[Cammell Laird|Laird, Son & Co.]], [[Birkenhead]] |Ship original cost= |Ship yard number= |Ship way number= |Ship laid down=9 November 1897 |Ship launched= 29 September 1898 |Ship sponsor= |Ship christened= |Ship completed=January 1900 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship renamed= |Ship reclassified= |Ship refit= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport= |Ship identification= |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship captured= |Ship fate=[[ship breaking|Scrapped]], 1922 |Ship status= |Ship notes= |Ship badge= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship Type=Destroyer |Ship displacement={{convert|360|LT|t|0|abbr=on}} |Ship length={{convert|216.25|ft|m|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|21.5|ft|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship draught={{convert|9|ft|7|in|m|1|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*[[Marine steam engine#Triple or multiple expansion|vertical triple-expansion steam engines]] *Coal-fired [[Normand boiler]]s *{{convert|6300|hp|0|abbr=on}} |Ship speed= {{convert|30|kn|lk=in}} |Ship range= |Ship endurance= |Ship complement= 63 |Ship armament=*1 × [[QF 12 pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12-pounder gun]] *2 × {{convert|18|in|mm|abbr=on}} [[torpedo tube]]s |Ship notes= }} |} '''HMS ''Orwell''''' was a [[B class destroyer (1913)|B-class]] [[torpedo boat destroyer]] of the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Royal Navy]]. She was built by [[Cammell Laird|Laird, Son & Company]], and served from 1900 until 1920.
==Construction and design== As part of the 1897–1898 construction programme for the Royal Navy, the British [[Admiralty]] placed an order with [[Cammell Laird|Laird, Son & Company]] of [[Birkenhead]] for a single "thirty-knotter" destroyer. Laird's design was based on the {{sclass-|Earnest|destroyer|2}} of six destroyers ordered under the 1895–1896 programme, which were in turn closely based on Laird's {{sclass-|Quail|destroyer|2}} ordered under the 1894–1895 programme.<ref name="lyon p61-3">Lyon 2001, pp. 61–63.</ref>
''Orwell'' had an [[overall length]] of {{convert|216|ft|9|in|m}}, with a [[Beam (nautical)|beam]] of {{convert|21|ft|6|in|m}} and a [[Draft (ship)|draught]] of {{convert|9|ft|7|in|m}}. The ship was powered by two [[Marine_steam_engine#Triple_or_multiple_expansion|triple expansion steam engines]], fed by four [[Normand boiler]]s, rated at {{convert|6300|ihp|kW|abbr=on|lk=in}} and was fitted with four funnels, giving a speed of 30 knots.<ref name="lyon p61,3">Lyon 2001, pp. 61, 63.</ref><ref name="conways60 p94">Chesneau and Kolesnik 1979, p. 94.</ref> [[Displacement (ship)|Displacement]] was {{convert|360|LT|t|0}} light and {{convert|410|LT|t|0}} full load.<ref name="conways60 p94"/>
Armament was as normal for the "thirty-knotters", with a [[QF 12 pounder 12 cwt naval gun|QF 12 pounder 12 cwt]] ({{convert|3|in|mm|abbr=on}} calibre) gun on a platform on the ship's [[conning tower]] (in practice the platform was also used as the ship's bridge), with a secondary armament of five 6-pounder guns, and two 18-inch (450 mm) torpedo tubes.<ref name="Lyon p98-9">Lyon 2001, pp. 98–99.</ref><ref name="Friedman p40">Friedman 2009, p. 40.</ref>
HMS ''Orwell'' was laid down on 9 November 1897 and launched on 29 September 1898.<ref name="lyon p63">Lyon 2001, p. 63.</ref>
==Service== ''Orwell'' completed in January 1900, joining the [[Mediterranean Fleet|Mediterranean Squadron]] in April that year.<ref name="lyon p63"/><ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=Naval & Military intelligence |day_of_week=Friday |date=19 April 1901 |page_number=10 |issue=36433| }}</ref> On 30 January 1903, ''Orwell'' collided with the cruiser [[HMAS Pioneer|HMS ''Pioneer'']] during night exercises near [[Corfu]]. ''Orwell''{{'}}s bow was cut off in the collision with the loss of 15 of her crew.<ref name="nmm">{{cite web|url=http://www.rmg.co.uk/upload/pdf/Warship_Histories_Vessels_iii.pdf|title=NMM, vessel ID 372552|work=Warship Histories, vol iii|publisher=[[National Maritime Museum]]|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cruiser and Destroyer in Collision: H.M.S. Orwell Run Down: Fifteen Petty Officers and Men Drowned|work=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=16 March 1903|page=6|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZH19030316.1.6&e=-------10--1----0--|accessdate=13 September 2014}}</ref>
''Orwell'' returned to the United Kingdom in 1906, remaining in home waters for the rest of her Royal Navy career.<ref name="lyon p63"/> In 1910, ''Orwell'' was part of the Fifth Destroyer Flotilla at [[HMNB Devonport|Devonport]], supported by the destroyer depot ship {{HMS|Leander|1882|2}}, and was still a part of the same flotilla in 1912.<ref name="nmm"/> On 30 August 1912 the Admiralty directed all destroyers were to be grouped into classes designated by letters based on appearance.<ref name="Conways06 p18">Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 18.</ref><ref name="manning p17-8">Manning 1961, pp. 17–18.</ref> As a four-funneled ship, ''Orwell'' was listed as a [[B-class destroyer (1913)|B-class destroyer]] on 1 October 1913.<ref name="Conways06 p73">Gardiner and Gray 1985, p. 73.</ref> By 1913, she was part as the Seventh Destroyer Flotilla,<ref name="nmm"/> still based at Devonport, one of four patrol flotillas equipped with older destroyers and torpedo boats.<ref name="manning p25">Manning 1961, p. 25.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Fleets, &c. at Home and Abroad: Patrol Flotillas|journal=The Navy List|date=April 1913|page=269d|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=94254982&mode=fullsize|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
On the outbreak of the [[First World War]], the Seventh Destroyer Flotilla was transferred to the East coast of the United Kingdom.<ref name="manning p25-6">Manning 1961, pp. 25–26.</ref> Late in 1914, ''Orwell'' was transferred to [[Scapa Flow]], where she carried out local patrol and escort duties.<ref name="nmm"/><ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officer's Commands, &c.|journal=The Navy List|date=January 1915|page=8|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=91953402&mode=fullsize|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref><ref name="manning p27">Manning 1961, p. 27.</ref> By March 1918, ''Orwell'' was one of only three destroyers assigned to local defence of Scapa,<ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officer's Commands, &c.|journal=The Navy List|date=March 1918|page=12|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92232994&mode=fullsize|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref> but by June that year she had been transferred to the Irish Sea Flotilla.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Supplement to the Monthly Naval List Showing Organisation of the Fleet, Flag Officer's Commands, &c.|journal=The Navy List|date=June 1918|page=19|url=http://digital.nls.uk/british-military-lists/pageturner.cfm?id=92263994|accessdate=14 September 2014}}</ref>
''Orwell'' was sold for scrap to S Castle of [[Plymouth]] on 1 July 1920 and was broken up in October 1922.<ref name="ditt p57">Dittmar and Colledge 1972, p. 57.</ref>
==References== {{Research help|Mil}} {{Reflist}}
*{{cite book|last1=Chesneau|first1=Roger|last2=Kolesnik|first2=Eugene M|title=Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1860–1905|year=1979|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-133-5}} *{{cite book|last1=Dittmar|first1=F.J.|last2=Colledge|first2=J.J.|title=British Warships 1914–1919|year=1972|publisher=Ian Allen|location=Shepperton, UK|isbn=0-7110-0380-7}} *{{cite book|last=Friedman|first=Norman|title=British Destroyers: From Earliest Days to the Second World War|year=2009|publisher=Seaforth Publishing|location=Barnsley, UK|isbn=978-1-84832-049-9}} * {{cite book|last1=Gardiner|first1=Robert|last2=Gray|first2=Randal|title=Conway's All The World's Fighting Ships 1906–1921|year=1985|publisher=Conway Maritime Press|location=London|isbn=0-85177-245-5}} * {{cite book|last=Lyon|first=David|title=The First Destroyers|year=2001|publisher=Caxton Editions|location=London|isbn=1-84067-3648}} *{{cite book|last=Manning|first=T. D.|title=The British Destroyer|year=1961|publisher=Putnam & Co. Ltd|location=London}}
